title: 2 Kings Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 6.

questions.question: What did the sons of the prophets say to Elisha about their dwelling place?
options: The place where we dwell with thee is too strait for us
The place is large enough for us all
We want to move to a city
We want to build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: The place where we dwell with thee is too strait for us
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:1 states that the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, 'Behold now, the place where we dwell with thee is too strait for us.'

questions.question: Where did the sons of the prophets want to go to get wood for a new place to dwell?
options: Jordan
Jericho
Samaria
Dothan
questions.correctAnswer: Jordan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:2 records that they wanted to go unto Jordan to take beams for building a place to dwell.

questions.question: What happened to the axe head while they were cutting wood at Jordan?
options: It fell into the water
It broke in two
It was stolen
It got stuck in a tree
questions.correctAnswer: It fell into the water
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 6:5, the axe head fell into the water while one was felling a beam.

questions.question: How did Elisha make the iron axe head float?
options: He cut down a stick and cast it into the water
He prayed and the water dried up
He stretched out his hand over the water
He asked the king to send help
questions.correctAnswer: He cut down a stick and cast it into the water
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:6 says Elisha cut down a stick and cast it into the water, making the iron float.

questions.question: Who was warred against by the king of Syria?
options: Israel
Judah
Egypt
Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:8 states that the king of Syria warred against Israel.

questions.question: What did the man of God warn the king of Israel about?
options: To beware and not pass certain places where the Syrians camped
To prepare for a feast
To build a new city
To send gifts to the king of Syria
questions.correctAnswer: To beware and not pass certain places where the Syrians camped
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:9 explains that the man of God sent word to warn the king of Israel about the places where the Syrians had come down.

questions.question: Where was Elisha when the king of Syria sent horses, chariots, and a great host to capture him?
options: Dothan
Samaria
Jerusalem
Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: Dothan
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:13 mentions that Elisha was in Dothan when the king of Syria sent forces to capture him.

questions.question: What did Elisha's servant see when his eyes were opened by the LORD?
options: The mountain full of horses and chariots of fire
The city surrounded by enemy soldiers
A great flood
A burning bush
questions.correctAnswer: The mountain full of horses and chariots of fire
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:17 states that the LORD opened the young man's eyes and he saw the mountain full of horses and chariots of fire around Elisha.

questions.question: What did Elisha do to the enemy soldiers when they came down to capture him?
options: Prayed and asked the LORD to strike them with blindness
Fought them with swords
Sent them away with gifts
Called the king of Israel for help
questions.correctAnswer: Prayed and asked the LORD to strike them with blindness
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:18 recounts that Elisha prayed and the LORD struck the enemy with blindness.

questions.question: What did Elisha instruct the blinded soldiers to do after he led them to Samaria?
options: Set bread and water before them and send them to their master
Put them in prison
Kill them
Release them immediately without food
questions.correctAnswer: Set bread and water before them and send them to their master
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:22 tells how Elisha instructed to feed the soldiers and then send them back to their master.

questions.question: What was the result after the bands of Syria were fed and sent away?
options: The bands of Syria came no more into the land of Israel
They attacked the next day
They made peace with Israel
They took Elisha captive
questions.correctAnswer: The bands of Syria came no more into the land of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:23 states that after being fed and sent away, the bands of Syria did not come into Israel again.

questions.question: What happened to Samaria after Benhadad king of Syria besieged it?
options: There was a great famine
It was immediately captured
It was flooded
It was abandoned
questions.correctAnswer: There was a great famine
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:25 states a great famine occurred in Samaria during the siege.

questions.question: True or False: The woman told the king that she and another woman had eaten their sons during the famine.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:28-29 shows the woman explaining to the king that they boiled and ate her son, and she was asked to give her son the next day but hid him.

questions.question: True or False: The king of Israel tore his clothes and wore sackcloth after hearing the woman's words about the famine.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:30 describes the king tearing his clothes and wearing sackcloth in response to the famine's severity.

questions.question: True or False: Elisha was afraid and fled when the king of Israel sent a messenger to take his head.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:32-33 shows Elisha calmly instructing the elders to shut the door and hold the messenger fast, recognizing the evil as from the LORD.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by the challenges they face and asks you for counsel. Based on 2 Kings 6, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's unseen help?
options: God’s protection is greater than visible threats.
We must rely only on our own strength.
Prayer is unnecessary in times of trouble.
Physical weapons are the only defense.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection is greater than visible threats.
questions.explanation: Elisha reassured his servant that those with them are more than those against them, and God revealed horses and chariots of fire (2 Kings 6:15-17). This shows God’s unseen protection is greater than visible threats.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 6 teach us about the importance of prayer in spiritual warfare and facing trials?
options: Prayer opens spiritual eyes to see God's power.
Prayer is only for personal requests.
Prayer should be avoided in times of danger.
Only prophets are allowed to pray.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer opens spiritual eyes to see God's power.
questions.explanation: Elisha prayed that God would open his servant’s eyes to see the heavenly army (2 Kings 6:17) and prayed for the enemy’s blindness (2 Kings 6:18), showing prayer's power in spiritual warfare.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear when faced with overwhelming opposition. According to 2 Kings 6, what practical step can help overcome this fear?
options: Trust in God’s greater power and pray for insight.
Hide and avoid all confrontations.
Give up on faith during trials.
Focus only on human plans.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s greater power and pray for insight.
questions.explanation: Elisha told his servant not to fear because those with them were more than those with the enemy, and he prayed for the servant’s eyes to be opened to see God’s protection (2 Kings 6:16-17).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 6 teach about honesty and integrity in daily work through the incident of the lost axe head?
options: Being truthful and responsible even for borrowed items is important.
It is acceptable to ignore losses if they are minor.
Stealing small things is not a big deal.
Blaming others is the best way to avoid trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: Being truthful and responsible even for borrowed items is important.
questions.explanation: When the borrowed axe head fell into the water, the man cried out honestly because it was borrowed (2 Kings 6:5), illustrating the value of honesty and responsibility at work.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 6 emphasize the virtue of generosity and kindness toward enemies?
options: Treat captured enemies with food and drink before sending them away.
Harm enemies whenever possible.
Ignore captured enemies to avoid trouble.
Demand ransom from prisoners.
questions.correctAnswer: Treat captured enemies with food and drink before sending them away.
questions.explanation: Elisha instructed the king not to harm the captured Syrians but to provide them with food and water and send them home (2 Kings 6:21-23), demonstrating generosity and mercy.

questions.question: A believer feels trapped by circumstances and lack of space for spiritual growth. What lesson does 2 Kings 6 provide about taking initiative and obedience?
options: Seek God’s guidance, then take practical steps like the sons of the prophets building a new dwelling.
Stay in uncomfortable places without change.
Wait passively for God to act without effort.
Disobey God's instructions to escape discomfort.
questions.correctAnswer: Seek God’s guidance, then take practical steps like the sons of the prophets building a new dwelling.
questions.explanation: The sons of the prophets asked Elisha to go with them to the Jordan to cut wood and build a place for dwelling, and he obeyed (2 Kings 6:1-4), illustrating practical obedience and initiative.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 6 teach about humility and dependence on God when facing impossible situations?
options: Recognize your limitations and ask God for help, as Elisha did with the lost axe head.
Rely only on human strength and ignore God.
Boast about your abilities instead of praying.
Avoid seeking help when in trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize your limitations and ask God for help, as Elisha did with the lost axe head.
questions.explanation: Elisha prayed and acted to help recover the lost axe head by casting a stick into the water, causing the iron to float (2 Kings 6:5-7), showing humility and trust in God’s help.

questions.question: True or False: Elisha encouraged the king of Israel to kill the captured Syrian soldiers immediately.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Elisha instructed the king not to kill the captives but to feed them and send them home (2 Kings 6:21-23), showing mercy and forgiveness.

questions.question: True or False: The king of Syria was frustrated because Elisha was revealing his military plans to Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The king of Syria was troubled because Elisha informed the king of Israel of his plans (2 Kings 6:11-12), revealing God's protection over Israel.

questions.question: When the Syrians surrounded Dothan to capture Elisha, how did Elisha respond to his servant’s fear, teaching us about faith and courage?
options: He told him not to fear because those with them are more than those with the enemy.
He encouraged him to run away immediately.
He said to hide and avoid the enemy.
He told him to fight the Syrians alone.
questions.correctAnswer: He told him not to fear because those with them are more than those with the enemy.
questions.explanation: Elisha reassured his servant that God's heavenly army was greater than the enemy’s forces, teaching faith and courage (2 Kings 6:15-16).

questions.question: How can the story of the famine in Samaria (2 Kings 6) encourage believers to persevere through trials?
options: Even severe trials like famine require trust in God's timing and deliverance.
Give up hope during hardships.
Ignore the needs of others in hard times.
Blame God for all difficulties.
questions.correctAnswer: Even severe trials like famine require trust in God's timing and deliverance.
questions.explanation: The famine and siege in Samaria were extreme (2 Kings 6:24-25), but Elisha’s ministry continued, and God's intervention was expected, encouraging perseverance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elisha’s response to the king’s messenger was, 'Behold, this evil is of the _______, what should I wait for the LORD any longer?'
options: LORD
enemy
king
people
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Elisha recognized the calamity as from the LORD himself and questioned the delay in God's action (2 Kings 6:33).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 6 teach about forgiveness and reconciliation in relation to enemies?
options: Forgive and provide for enemies when they are vulnerable, as Elisha instructed feeding captured Syrians.
Seek revenge immediately.
Avoid any contact with enemies.
Hold grudges and refuse peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Forgive and provide for enemies when they are vulnerable, as Elisha instructed feeding captured Syrians.
questions.explanation: Elisha’s command to feed the captured Syrians and send them home peacefully demonstrates forgiveness and reconciliation (2 Kings 6:21-23).

questions.question: How does the account of the woman speaking to the king during the famine teach about the reality of suffering and the need for compassion?
options: It reveals the extreme suffering endured and calls for compassionate leadership and trust in God.
It suggests suffering is a sign of God’s punishment only.
It advises ignoring the poor and needy.
It encourages blaming victims for their plight.
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals the extreme suffering endured and calls for compassionate leadership and trust in God.
questions.explanation: The woman described horrific famine conditions (2 Kings 6:26-29), and the king’s reaction (2 Kings 6:30) shows the call for compassion and reliance on God.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 6, what spiritual lesson can be learned from Elisha praying to blind the Syrian army?
options: Prayer can be used to protect God’s people and bring about deliverance.
Prayer has no effect on enemies.
Violence is the only solution to conflict.
Spiritual leaders should not intervene in battles.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer can be used to protect God’s people and bring about deliverance.
questions.explanation: Elisha prayed for the Syrians to be blinded, which God granted, protecting Israel (2 Kings 6:18-19), showing the power of prayer in deliverance.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 6.

questions.question: In 2 Kings 6, what miracle does Elisha perform involving an axe head?
options: He makes the axe head float on water
He turns the axe head into gold
He breaks the axe head in two
He calls down fire to consume the axe head
questions.correctAnswer: He makes the axe head float on water
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:6-7, Elisha cuts down a stick and throws it into the water at the place where the axe head fell, causing the iron to float so it could be retrieved.

questions.question: What city was Elisha located in when the king of Syria sent horses and chariots to capture him?
options: Dothan
Samaria
Jericho
Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Dothan
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 6:13-14, Elisha was in Dothan when the king of Syria sent a great host of horses and chariots to capture him.

questions.question: What does Elisha pray for regarding his servant’s eyes in 2 Kings 6?
options: To see the mountain full of horses and chariots of fire
To see the future of Israel
To see the king of Syria’s plans
To see the path to Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: To see the mountain full of horses and chariots of fire
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:17, Elisha prays that the LORD open his servant’s eyes so that he may see the spiritual army protecting them, described as horses and chariots of fire.

questions.question: What was the king of Syria’s reaction to his repeated military failures against Israel as described in 2 Kings 6?
options: He was sore troubled and sought to capture Elisha
He made peace with Israel
He increased his offerings to pagan gods
He withdrew his armies immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He was sore troubled and sought to capture Elisha
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:11-13 shows that the king of Syria was deeply troubled and asked his servants to find out who was revealing his plans, leading to the attempt to capture Elisha.

questions.question: How did Elisha respond to the Syrian soldiers when they were captured in Samaria?
options: He instructed the king to feed them and send them back to their master
He told the king to execute them all
He asked the king to imprison them indefinitely
He sent them back without food or water
questions.correctAnswer: He instructed the king to feed them and send them back to their master
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:22-23, Elisha advises the king not to harm the captives but to provide food and water before sending them back, which led to peace.

questions.question: What severe condition afflicted Samaria during the siege by Benhadad king of Syria?
options: A great famine
A widespread plague
A violent earthquake
A locust infestation
questions.correctAnswer: A great famine
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:24-25 describes the siege of Samaria and the resulting great famine, with extreme prices for food illustrating the severity of the crisis.

questions.question: The phrase in 2 Kings 6:25 mentioning 'an ass's head was sold for fourscore pieces of silver' illustrates what kind of literary device?
options: Hyperbole to emphasize the famine's severity
Metaphor describing political corruption
Allegory for spiritual decay
Paradox contrasting abundance and scarcity
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to emphasize the famine's severity
questions.explanation: This verse uses hyperbole, an exaggerated statement, to stress how scarce and expensive food had become during the famine caused by the siege.

questions.question: In the context of 2 Kings 6, what does Elisha’s ability to reveal the king of Syria’s military plans foreshadow in biblical typology?
options: The prophetic insight and divine protection over Israel
The downfall of the Davidic kingdom
The coming exile to Babylon
The ministry of John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: The prophetic insight and divine protection over Israel
questions.explanation: Elisha’s knowledge of the enemy’s plans, granted by God, typifies the divine protection and prophetic guidance given to Israel, a recurring theme in the biblical narrative.

questions.question: What is the significance of Elisha’s prayer to blind the Syrian army according to the historical and cultural context of the ancient Near East?
options: It demonstrates reliance on divine intervention instead of conventional warfare
It was a common military tactic to physically blind enemies
It shows Elisha’s power as a king
It reflects the pagan practice of cursing enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates reliance on divine intervention instead of conventional warfare
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, spiritual power was often seen as superior; Elisha’s prayer to blind the enemy reflects Israel’s trust in God’s intervention over human military strength (2 Kings 6:18).

questions.question: Which theme in 2 Kings 6 is developed across Scripture and relates to God's unseen protection?
options: The spiritual warfare and divine guardianship over God's people
The eventual destruction of Israel
The law of Moses given at Sinai
The building of the Temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The spiritual warfare and divine guardianship over God's people
questions.explanation: The vision of horses and chariots of fire in 2 Kings 6:17 illustrates God's unseen protection, a theme echoed throughout Scripture in passages like Psalm 91 and Revelation.

questions.question: True or False: The king of Israel immediately executed the Syrian captives upon Elisha’s instruction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:22-23 clearly states that instead of executing the captives, the king prepared food and water and sent them back, following Elisha’s instructions.

questions.question: What does the reaction of the king of Israel to the woman’s story during the famine reveal about his leadership?
options: He was deeply distressed and repented
He ignored the pleas of his people
He blamed the prophets for the famine
He immediately surrendered to the Syrians
questions.correctAnswer: He was deeply distressed and repented
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:30-31, the king rents his clothes and wears sackcloth, showing distress and repentance over the desperate situation, demonstrating a leadership burdened by the people's suffering.

questions.question: How does Elisha’s interaction with the elders and the messenger in 2 Kings 6:32-33 illustrate the theme of divine sovereignty?
options: Elisha recognizes that the evil is from the LORD and submits to His will
Elisha attempts to negotiate peace with the Syrians
Elisha flees to avoid capture
Elisha commands the king to retaliate immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha recognizes that the evil is from the LORD and submits to His will
questions.explanation: Elisha's statement in 2 Kings 6:33 that this evil is from the LORD reflects the biblical theme of divine sovereignty and submission even in hardship.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is reflected by Elisha leading the blinded Syrian army into Samaria and then restoring their sight?
options: Mercy and restoration over judgment
Retribution and punishment
Isolation of the enemy
Covenantal curses
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and restoration over judgment
questions.explanation: Elisha’s actions in 2 Kings 6:19-20 embody mercy and restoration by not harming the captives and restoring their sight, reflecting God’s gracious character.

questions.question: The sons of the prophets’ desire to move and build a place near Jordan (2 Kings 6:1-2) can be interpreted as a typology for what biblical motif?
options: The expansion and renewal of prophetic ministry
The exile to Babylon
The establishment of the monarchy
The building of Solomon’s temple
questions.correctAnswer: The expansion and renewal of prophetic ministry
questions.explanation: Their wish to enlarge their dwelling and build near the Jordan represents growth and renewal of prophetic community, a motif of spiritual revival in Scripture.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological truth is illustrated by Elisha causing the iron axe head to float when it fell into the water?
options: God's sovereign power over nature
The importance of craftsmanship
The inevitability of human failure
The power of prayer alone
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign power over nature
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:5-7, Elisha demonstrates God's control over nature by causing the borrowed iron axe head to float, illustrating God's sovereignty over creation. This is consistent with biblical affirmations of God's authority over nature (Psalm 104:14-15, Matthew 8:26-27, Colossians 1:16-17, Hebrews 1:3).

questions.question: Why did the king of Syria become troubled according to 2 Kings 6?
options: Because Elisha warned the king of Israel of his plans
Because his army was defeated in battle
Because he lost his horses and chariots
Because of a famine in his land
questions.correctAnswer: Because Elisha warned the king of Israel of his plans
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:8-11, the king of Syria was troubled because Elisha informed the king of Israel about his military plans, foiling his attempts. This reflects God's providential protection over His people (Exodus 14:13-14, Psalm 34:7, Isaiah 37:33-35, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What does the opening of the servant's eyes to see the mountain full of horses and chariots of fire demonstrate about God?
options: God's invisible spiritual protection over His servants
That human sight is unreliable
That war is inevitable
That Elisha was delusional
questions.correctAnswer: God's invisible spiritual protection over His servants
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:17 shows that God reveals spiritual realities to His servants, indicating His omnipresent protection. This aligns with biblical teaching on spiritual warfare and God's guardianship (Psalm 91:11-12, Ephesians 6:12-13, 2 Corinthians 10:3-5, Hebrews 1:14).

questions.question: How did Elisha respond when the Syrian army surrounded the city and his servant was afraid?
options: He told him not to fear because those with them were more than those with the enemy
He instructed to fight immediately
He fled the city
He prayed for destruction of the enemy
questions.correctAnswer: He told him not to fear because those with them were more than those with the enemy
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:15-16, Elisha reassures his servant by affirming God's greater power and protection, highlighting the doctrine of God's sovereignty and faithfulness to His people (Deuteronomy 20:4, Psalm 46:1-3, Isaiah 41:10, Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What does Elisha's prayer to smite the Syrian army with blindness reveal about God's power?
options: God can supernaturally control human senses
God is indifferent to human warfare
God punishes all enemies without mercy
God only works through natural means
questions.correctAnswer: God can supernaturally control human senses
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:18, Elisha prays and God blinds the enemy, demonstrating God's ability to intervene supernaturally in human affairs, consistent with other biblical accounts (Exodus 10:21-23, Isaiah 29:10, Acts 9:8-9, 2 Corinthians 12:7-9).

questions.question: What is the significance of Elisha leading the blind Syrian army into Samaria instead of their intended destination?
options: It shows God's control over circumstances to protect His people
It was a trick by Elisha for personal gain
It was a mistake due to poor guidance
It shows the Syrians' superior knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's control over circumstances to protect His people
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:19-20 shows Elisha leading the enemy into Samaria, illustrating God’s providential care and sovereignty over events for the benefit of His people (Genesis 50:20, Exodus 23:23, Psalm 33:10-11, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Why did Elisha instruct the king of Israel not to kill the captured Syrian soldiers but to feed and send them away?
options: To show mercy and prevent further vengeance
Because they were too many to kill
Because they were innocent
Because the king ordered it
questions.correctAnswer: To show mercy and prevent further vengeance
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:21-23, Elisha teaches mercy by feeding and releasing captives, reflecting God's call for compassion and peace (Proverbs 25:21-22, Matthew 5:44, Romans 12:20-21, Luke 6:27-36).

questions.question: What doctrine is illustrated by the famine and siege of Samaria described in 2 Kings 6:24-25?
options: God's judgment on a nation for sin
The randomness of natural disasters
The inevitability of war
Human self-sufficiency in crisis
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment on a nation for sin
questions.explanation: The famine and siege in Samaria (2 Kings 6:24-25) demonstrate God's righteous judgment on Israel, consistent with the biblical theme of divine discipline for sin (Deuteronomy 28:15-68, 2 Chronicles 36:15-21, Hebrews 12:5-11, Revelation 3:19).

questions.question: What does the dialogue between the king of Israel and the woman during the famine reveal about human depravity in crisis?
options: Desperation can lead to extreme sin and broken social order
People always trust God in crisis
Faith never wavers in famine
Kings always have solutions
questions.correctAnswer: Desperation can lead to extreme sin and broken social order
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:26-29 reveals how famine leads to horrific sin such as cannibalism, illustrating the fallen nature of humanity apart from God's provision and order (Romans 3:23, Jeremiah 14:18, Lamentations 4:10, Matthew 24:7).

questions.question: What does the king of Israel's reaction to the woman's story tell us about his attitude towards God's prophet Elisha?
options: He was protective and trusted Elisha
He was indifferent to Elisha
He wanted to replace Elisha
He doubted Elisha's authority
questions.correctAnswer: He was protective and trusted Elisha
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:30-31, the king mourns the plight of his people and vows to protect Elisha, showing respect for the prophet’s role and God's messenger, reflecting biblical respect for God’s servants (1 Kings 19:18, Malachi 3:1, Hebrews 11:32-38, 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13).

questions.question: What does Elisha’s awareness of the king’s plot against him teach about divine sovereignty over human plans?
options: God is sovereign even over evil human schemes
God is unaware of human intentions
God approves of all human plots
God is powerless against rulers
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign even over evil human schemes
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 6:32-33, Elisha knows about the king’s plan to seize him, illustrating that God’s sovereignty extends over human intentions and evil designs (Psalm 33:10-11, Proverbs 19:21, Isaiah 14:27, Daniel 2:21).

questions.question: How does Elisha's statement that the evil is of the LORD in 2 Kings 6:33 contribute to the doctrine of God's justice?
options: God’s justice includes permitting or ordaining judgment as part of His righteous plan
God is not involved in human affairs
God always prevents evil
God is indifferent to evil
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice includes permitting or ordaining judgment as part of His righteous plan
questions.explanation: Elisha’s declaration (2 Kings 6:33) underscores that God’s justice can involve permitting evil or judgment for His purposes, consistent with Scripture’s teaching on God's righteous governance (Isaiah 45:7, Romans 1:18-32, Lamentations 3:37-38, Job 1:12).

questions.question: What does the repeated success of Israel escaping Syrian attacks due to Elisha’s warnings teach about God's providence?
options: God providentially protects His people through His prophets
God allows His people to be destroyed without warning
Prophets were unreliable in warfare
God only protects the strong
questions.correctAnswer: God providentially protects His people through His prophets
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:9-10 shows God's providence in saving Israel by revealing enemy plans through Elisha, consistent with God's protective care through His servants (Exodus 23:23, Psalm 91:1-16, Isaiah 54:17, John 10:27-29).

questions.question: What aspect of God's character is reflected in Elisha’s prayer for the servant's eyes to be opened to see the heavenly army?
options: God’s revelation of spiritual realities to His people
God’s hiddenness from humanity
God’s judgment without warning
God’s indifference to spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: God’s revelation of spiritual realities to His people
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 6:17 highlights God’s revelation as He opens the servant’s eyes to see the heavenly army, showing God’s active involvement and communication with His people (John 1:18, Hebrews 1:14, Ephesians 1:17-18, 1 Corinthians 2:10).

questions.question: What eschatological theme can be drawn from the fiery chariots surrounding Elisha in 2 Kings 6:17?
options: The reality of angelic hosts protecting God’s people before Christ’s return
The inevitability of earthly war ending all conflict
The final destruction of all armies by fire
The supremacy of human armies over spiritual beings
questions.correctAnswer: The reality of angelic hosts protecting God’s people before Christ’s return
questions.explanation: The fiery chariots (2 Kings 6:17) symbolize angelic protection, pointing to biblical teachings on angelic ministry and protection until the eschaton (Psalm 34:7, Daniel 10:13, Revelation 19:14, Hebrews 1:14).
